abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            strengthening the banking system to promote rural
            investments in Vietnam. Term lending to rural areas was
            insufficient to lift a large proportion of the rural
            population out of poverty. Rural Finance Projects financed a
            wide range of rural investments to 4.45 million families and
            small enterprises whose net incomes rose by an average of 65
            percent. Investment lending by twenty five participating
            financial institutions to private rural entrepreneurs
            increased fourteen-fold and the volume of lending to the
            poor and to micro-enterprises jumped 250 percent. The
            quality and range of financial services improved, and all
            participating institutions improved their risk and credit
            management system.

Viet Nam - Encourager l'investissement
            en milieu rural

repnme.cdata!:
Stronger banking systems for Vietnam's
            rural poor

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            stronger banking systems for the Vietnam's rural poor.
            In Vietnam three-quarters of the whole population and 85
            percent of the poor lived in rural areas. Because of the
            small size of farms, agricultural growth needed to be
            combined with non-farm employment to make a sustained attack
            on rural poverty. The flow of term lending to the rural
            areas was insufficient to meet the investment needed to
            increase output and to lift a large proportion of the rural
            population out of poverty. The Second Rural Finance Project
            was implemented between 2003 and 2009 to spur rural
            investments throughout Vietnam. As a result, the income of
            the rural population rose by 65 percent and generated an
            estimated 2.74 million additional jobs. Finally, the project
            also led to the improvement in financial services and risk
            and credit management systems.

docna.cdata!:
Des systèmes bancaires plus solides pour les
            populations rurales pauvres du Viet Nam

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Rural Finance
            Project for Vietnam were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: when a government is taking a series of measures
            to improve conditions in rural areas, and rural term credit
            is in short supply, easing this constraint can have a major
            positive impact on rural incomes. It also leads to increases
            in access to other financial services such as use of savings
            deposits. Credit projects are likely to succeed when they
            are relatively straightforward in structure, provided that
            the broad financial sector reform issues have been or are
            being addressed at the same time. A local commercial bank,
            if suitably strengthened, may be in the best position to
            serve as an apex lending institution, provided that there is
            strong commitment from its senior management including
            willingness to provide the necessary resources to a Project
            Management Unit (PMU) and to set up an effective Monitoring
            and Evaluation (M&E) system. A strong PMU can be used as
            a training ground for its larger institution, provided the
            institution's senior management is committed to this
            rather than isolating the PMU. Private Banks can be
            attracted to significantly expand term credit in rural
            areas, provided they have access to longer-term funds and
            receive appropriate training and Technical Assistance (TA).
            It is feasible to have vigorous competition among banks,
            even in poor rural areas. Environmental standards can be
            introduced even for small sub-borrowers, provided that
            emphasis is given to education and not just regulation. This
            is especially important in activities like livestock and
            aquaculture. Job creation, in relation to investment
            amounts, is much greater for small subprojects than for
            larger ones. Beneficiary surveys should be built into credit
            projects, and should preferably be carried out by or at
            least with the participation of independent entities.

15354119.trustfund: TF040433-VIETNAM:  RURAL FINANCE II,TF040435-VIETNAM:  RURAL FINANCE II,TF040479-VIETNAM:  RURAL FINANCE II

repnme.cdata!: Extending credit to the rural poor of Vietnam

abstracts.cdata!:
Between 1998 and 2001, a World
            Bank-assisted Rural Finance project provided nearly $650,000
            to 250,000 rural Vietnam households. Almost a third of the
            borrowers were women. The loans, averaging $360 each and
            provided through seven participating banks, were used to
            expand farm production, agricultural processing, and
            trading. Without the project, most of these borrowers would
            have reportedly turned to money lenders, whose costs are
            much higher. The total credit provided by the Bank for this
            project was $110 million. The project has supported several
            financing initiatives, one of them being mobile banking,
            which provides services to remote areas without bank
            branches. Already, the benefits of mobile banking exceed the
            costs, highlighting the need to provide more and better
            banking services to people in remote areas who until now
            have had no formal banks to serve them.

docna.cdata!: Extending credit to the rural poor of Vietnam

Extending credit to the rural
